source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk1
evidence_span: Tubing was produced from sponge-based ingots of the following nominal compositions: Zr-0.5Nb, Zr-1.0Nb, Zr-2.5Nb, and Zr-1.0Nb-1.0Sn-0.1Fe. These compositions are designated alloys A, B, C, and E, respectively.

extra_properties.processing_philosophy: beta treat at intermediate stage, alternately pilger and anneal

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk5

evidence_span: from 21 to 42 μm on a second high power Zircaloy-4 rod

extra_properties.crud_effect: thicker corrosion underneath crud (38 μm average, 42 μm peak) vs crud-free regions (26 μm average, 33 μm peak)

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk6

extra_properties.hydrogen_absorption_rate: constant rate independent of cladding type

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk6
evidence_span: autoclave corrosion testing in pure water over the temperature range of 589 to 727 K
process_step: fabricated with second phase fully precipitated
corrosion_data: lower post-transition corrosion rate than Zircaloy-4

extra_properties.microstructure: second phase fully precipitated as discrete uniformly distributed particles with minimal particle growth
extra_properties.breakaway_tendency: 0.5% Nb and 1.0% Nb alloys show tendency to breakaway into higher corrosion rates

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk6
evidence_span: quaternary composition containing tin, niobium, and iron
conditions: high temperature steam, high lithia solutions, BR-3 reactor
corrosion_data: excellent performance, no breakaway corrosion at temperatures of 686 K or greater

extra_properties.breakaway_resistance: no tendency for breakaway corrosion at ≥686 K
extra_properties.lithia_resistance: enhanced resistance to lithia concentration attack

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Autoclave testing in lithiated water solutions indicated a marked sensitivity of the niobium binaries to accelerated corrosion; only the ZIRLO alloy was superior to Zircaloy4 in this test regime.

extra_properties.corrosion_performance: superior to Zircaloy-4 in lithiated water

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The in-reactor waterside corrosion performance of the ZIRLO alloy was better than that of reference Zircaloy-4 cladding. The relative corrosion performance benefit of ZIRLO over Zircaloy-4 increased with increasing power levels.

extra_properties.corrosion_performance: better than Zircaloy-4, improves with increasing power

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The ZIRLO alloy showed significantly lower in-reactor creep and rod growth than Zircaloy-4 and the niobium binary alloys.
irradiation_creep_data: significantly lower than Zircaloy-4 and Nb binaries

extra_properties.rod_growth: significantly lower than Zircaloy-4 and Nb binaries

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: The corrosion performance of the binary zirconium-niobium alloys showed locally thicker oxides and greater variability than exhibited by either ZIRLO or Zircaloy-4.
corrosion_data: locally thicker oxides and greater variability

source_id: STP1023-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_8th Volume_018_chunk7
evidence_span: Enhanced Low-Temperature Oxidation of Zirconium Alloys Under Irradiation

extra_properties.oxidation_behavior: enhanced under irradiation at low temperatures
